slides.title: Welcome to Human Physiology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Human Physiology

Welcome to **Human Physiology** - how your body works!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Organ Systems** - Body systems working together
- **Homeostasis** - Maintaining balance
- **Nervous System** - Control and communication
- **Circulatory System** - Transport network
- **Respiratory System** - Gas exchange

> **Fun Fact:** Your body has about 78 organs and 11 organ systems!

## Levels of Organization:
1. Cells -> Tissues -> Organs -> Organ Systems -> Organism

## Major Organ Systems:

| System | Main Function |
|--------|---------------|
| Nervous | Control, communication |
| Circulatory | Transport |
| Respiratory | Gas exchange |
| Digestive | Nutrient processing |
| Immune | Defense |
| Endocrine | Hormones |
| Muscular | Movement |
| Skeletal | Support, protection |

slides.title: Homeostasis
slides.content:
# Homeostasis

**Homeostasis:** Maintaining stable internal conditions

## Key Variables Regulated:
- Temperature (37 C / 98.6 F)
- Blood glucose (70-110 mg/dL)
- Blood pH (7.35-7.45)
- Water/salt balance
- Blood pressure

## Feedback Loops:

### Negative Feedback:
- Response opposes change
- Maintains set point
- Most common

**Example - Temperature:**
1. Temperature rises
2. Sensors detect change
3. Brain signals response
4. Sweating, vasodilation
5. Temperature decreases

### Positive Feedback:
- Response amplifies change
- Rare, specific situations

**Examples:**
- Childbirth contractions
- Blood clotting
- Lactation

## Components:

| Component | Function |
|-----------|----------|
| Receptor | Detects change |
| Control center | Processes information |
| Effector | Makes response |

slides.title: Nervous System
slides.content:
# Nervous System

## Divisions:

**Central Nervous System (CNS):**
- Brain and spinal cord
- Processing center

**Peripheral Nervous System (PNS):**
- Nerves throughout body
- Carries signals to/from CNS

## Neurons:

**Structure:**
- Dendrites: Receive signals
- Cell body: Contains nucleus
- Axon: Transmits signal
- Synaptic terminals: Release neurotransmitters

## Signal Transmission:

**Action Potential:**
1. Resting potential (-70 mV)
2. Stimulus opens Na+ channels
3. Depolarization (Na+ rushes in)
4. Repolarization (K+ rushes out)
5. Signal travels down axon

**Synapse:**
1. Action potential arrives
2. Neurotransmitters released
3. Bind to receptors on next neuron
4. New signal generated

## Brain Regions:

| Region | Function |
|--------|----------|
| Cerebrum | Thinking, senses |
| Cerebellum | Coordination |
| Brainstem | Vital functions |
| Hypothalamus | Homeostasis |

slides.title: Circulatory System
slides.content:
# Circulatory System

## Components:
- Heart (pump)
- Blood vessels (transport)
- Blood (medium)

## The Heart:
- Four chambers: 2 atria, 2 ventricles
- Right side: deoxygenated blood to lungs
- Left side: oxygenated blood to body

## Blood Flow Path:
```
Body -> Right atrium -> Right ventricle
-> Lungs -> Left atrium -> Left ventricle
-> Body
```

## Blood Vessels:

| Type | Function | Features |
|------|----------|----------|
| Arteries | Away from heart | Thick walls, elastic |
| Veins | To heart | Valves, thin walls |
| Capillaries | Exchange | Thin, one cell thick |

## Blood Composition:

| Component | Function |
|-----------|----------|
| Red blood cells | Carry O2 |
| White blood cells | Immune defense |
| Platelets | Clotting |
| Plasma | Transport medium |

## Blood Pressure:
- Systolic: Heart contracting (120 mmHg normal)
- Diastolic: Heart relaxing (80 mmHg normal)
- Hypertension: High blood pressure (>140/90)

slides.title: Respiratory System
slides.content:
# Respiratory System

## Function:
- Gas exchange (O2 in, CO2 out)
- pH regulation
- Voice production

## Pathway:
```
Nose/Mouth -> Pharynx -> Larynx -> Trachea
-> Bronchi -> Bronchioles -> Alveoli
```

## Alveoli:
- Site of gas exchange
- Thin walls (one cell)
- Surrounded by capillaries
- Large surface area (~70 m^2)

## Gas Exchange:
- Diffusion based on concentration gradients
- O2: Alveoli -> Blood
- CO2: Blood -> Alveoli

## Breathing Mechanics:

**Inhalation:**
- Diaphragm contracts (flattens)
- Ribcage expands
- Lung volume increases
- Pressure decreases, air flows in

**Exhalation:**
- Diaphragm relaxes
- Ribcage contracts
- Lung volume decreases
- Pressure increases, air flows out

## Oxygen Transport:
- Hemoglobin in red blood cells
- Each hemoglobin carries 4 O2
- Oxyhemoglobin (with O2)
- Deoxyhemoglobin (without O2)

slides.title: Digestive System
slides.content:
# Digestive System

## Function:
- Break down food
- Absorb nutrients
- Eliminate waste

## GI Tract:

| Organ | Function |
|-------|----------|
| Mouth | Mechanical, begin starch digestion |
| Esophagus | Transport |
| Stomach | Protein digestion, acid |
| Small intestine | Most digestion and absorption |
| Large intestine | Water absorption, waste |

## Accessory Organs:

| Organ | Secretion |
|-------|----------|
| Salivary glands | Amylase |
| Liver | Bile |
| Pancreas | Enzymes, bicarbonate |
| Gallbladder | Stores bile |

## Enzymes:

| Enzyme | Substrate | Product |
|--------|-----------|--------|
| Amylase | Starch | Maltose |
| Pepsin | Proteins | Peptides |
| Lipase | Fats | Fatty acids |
| Trypsin | Proteins | Amino acids |

## Small Intestine:
- Villi increase surface area
- Microvilli on cells
- Nutrients absorbed into blood/lymph

slides.title: Immune System
slides.content:
# Immune System

## Lines of Defense:

### 1st Line: Physical Barriers
- Skin
- Mucous membranes
- Stomach acid

### 2nd Line: Innate Immunity
- Non-specific
- Phagocytes (macrophages, neutrophils)
- Inflammation
- Fever

### 3rd Line: Adaptive Immunity
- Specific to pathogen
- Memory
- B cells and T cells

## Lymphocytes:

**B Cells:**
- Make antibodies
- Humoral immunity

**T Cells:**
- Helper T cells (coordinate response)
- Cytotoxic T cells (kill infected cells)
- Cell-mediated immunity

## Antibodies:
- Y-shaped proteins
- Specific to antigens
- Neutralize, mark for destruction

## Immunity Types:

| Type | Source | Example |
|------|--------|--------|
| Active natural | Infection | Getting sick |
| Active artificial | Vaccine | Immunization |
| Passive natural | Mother | Breast milk |
| Passive artificial | Injection | Antivenom |

slides.title: Endocrine System
slides.content:
# Endocrine System

## Function:
- Hormone production
- Long-term regulation
- Works with nervous system

## Major Glands:

| Gland | Hormones | Functions |
|-------|----------|----------|
| Pituitary | Growth hormone, TSH | Master gland |
| Thyroid | Thyroxine | Metabolism |
| Adrenal | Adrenaline, cortisol | Stress response |
| Pancreas | Insulin, glucagon | Blood sugar |
| Gonads | Testosterone, estrogen | Reproduction |

## Hormone Types:

**Steroid hormones:**
- Enter cell
- Bind receptors in nucleus
- Example: Testosterone, estrogen

**Peptide hormones:**
- Cannot enter cell
- Bind membrane receptors
- Second messenger system
- Example: Insulin

## Blood Sugar Regulation:

**High glucose:**
- Pancreas releases insulin
- Cells take up glucose
- Glucose stored as glycogen

**Low glucose:**
- Pancreas releases glucagon
- Glycogen broken down
- Glucose released

slides.title: Excretory System
slides.content:
# Excretory System

## Function:
- Remove metabolic wastes
- Regulate water/salt balance
- Maintain blood pH

## Kidneys:

**Nephron structure:**
- Glomerulus: Filtration
- Proximal tubule: Reabsorption
- Loop of Henle: Concentration
- Distal tubule: Secretion
- Collecting duct: Final concentration

## Urine Formation:

### 1. Filtration:
- Blood filtered in glomerulus
- Small molecules pass through
- Cells and proteins stay

### 2. Reabsorption:
- Useful substances returned to blood
- Glucose, amino acids, water, salts

### 3. Secretion:
- Additional wastes added to filtrate
- H+, K+, drugs

## Regulation:

**ADH (Antidiuretic hormone):**
- Increases water reabsorption
- Concentrated urine when dehydrated

**Aldosterone:**
- Increases Na+ reabsorption
- Water follows Na+

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Human Physiology Summary

## Homeostasis:
- Maintaining stable internal conditions
- Negative feedback (most common)
- Set points for temperature, pH, glucose

## Major Systems:

| System | Key Function |
|--------|-------------|
| Nervous | Rapid communication |
| Circulatory | Transport |
| Respiratory | Gas exchange |
| Digestive | Nutrient processing |
| Immune | Defense |
| Endocrine | Hormone regulation |
| Excretory | Waste removal |

## Key Comparisons:

| Nervous | Endocrine |
|---------|----------|
| Fast | Slow |
| Electrical | Chemical |
| Short-term | Long-term |

## Blood Glucose:
- Insulin: decreases glucose
- Glucagon: increases glucose

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Human Physiology!
